revision.text:
{{other people|Jennifer Thomas}} {{Infobox musical artist |name = Jennifer Thomas |image = Jennifer_Thomas_(pianist).jpg |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1977|6|23}} |origin = [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]], [[United States]] |genre = [[classical music|Classical]], [[Crossover (music)|crossover]], [[new-age music|new-age]]. |background = non_vocal_instrumentalist |instruments = [[Piano]], [[violin]] |label = [[Independent record label|Independent]] |website = {{URL|www.jenniferthomasmusic.com}} }}
'''Jennifer Thomas''' (born June 23, 1977) is a multi award-winning [[Yamaha Artist]] and ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' charting American pianist, violinist, composer, performing artist, and recording artist. She was classically trained at [[Brigham Young University-Idaho]], and started composing in 2003, later releasing her first debut album in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://jenniferthomasmusic.wordpress.com/my-story/|title=My Story|author=|date=|work=Musical Meanderings|accessdate=2015-10-09}}</ref><ref name="Sound Publishing Inc">{{Cite web|title = Her sounds of the season - Sequim Gazette|url = http://www.sequimgazette.com/entertainment/351063821.html|website = Sequim Gazette|publisher = Sound Publishing Inc|access-date = 2016-01-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://scvelitemagazine.com/2017/11/words-wisdom-dont-need-one/|title=Words Of Wisdom – we don’t need to be the same to be one - élite Magazine|date=2017-11-21|work=élite Magazine|access-date=2017-11-23|language=en-US}}</ref> Thomas has issued six albums, the latest album [[The Fire Within - Jennifer Thomas (pianist) album|The Fire Within]] was released in October 2018, which debuted at number 3 in the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Classical music]] charts and number 2 in their Classical [[Crossover music]] charts.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/classical-albums|title=Classical Music: Top Classical Albums Chart|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-10-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/biz/charts/classical-crossover-albums|title=Classical Crossover Albums : Page 1 {{!}} Billboard|website=Billboard|language=en|access-date=2018-10-23}}</ref>
==Career== Thomas is known for writing and performing piano-centered orchestral music from [[classical music]] to [[classical music]] [[crossover (music)|crossover]] and cinematic orchestral Epic music. While most of her works are original, she also covers classical pieces as well as pop music and movie soundtracks. Thomas has also composed film scores, where she won the Gold Medal of Excellence in the 2011 [[Park City Film Music Festival]] for "Music in a Short Film" <ref name="pcfmf.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.pcfmf.com/past.html |title=2011 Award Winners |publisher=Pcfmf.com |accessdate=2015-10-13}}</ref> as well as a 2012 Hollywood Music in Media Award for "Best Film Score for Documentary/Short".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hmmawards.com/2012-visual-media-nominees/ |title=Music Awards Los Angeles | Music Awards Hollywood |publisher=Hmmawards.com |date= |accessdate=2015-10-13}}</ref>
Thomas' third album, "Illumination" won "Album of the Year" and "Artist of the Year" at the 2013 IMC Awards.<ref name="firstpost.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.firstpost.com/topic/place/seattle-wa-illumination-album-trailer-jennifer-thomas-classical-cr-video-QK1BVzqVNv4-93-17.html |title="Illumination" Album Trailer - Jennifer Thomas (Classical Crossover Pianist/Violinist/Composer), Video |publisher=Firstpost |date=2015-07-29 |accessdate=2015-10-13}}</ref><ref name="jenniferthomasmusic.wordpress.com">{{cite web|url=https://jenniferthomasmusic.wordpress.com/my-story/ |title=Musical Meanderings : The Official Blog of Pianist and Composer Jennifer Thomas : My Story |publisher=Jenniferthomasmusic.wordpress.com |accessdate=2015-10-13}}</ref> In October 2015 "Illumination" also won the "Classical Song of the Year" International Music and Entertainment Association Award,<ref>{{Cite web|title = 2015 Winners {{!}} IMEA Awards|url = http://www.imeaawards.com/winners/2015-winners/|website = www.imeaawards.com|access-date = 2016-01-11}}</ref> and the Enlightened Piano Radio Award for "Best piano album with instrumentation" at [[Carnegie Hall]] [[New York City]] - where she performed live at the awards ceremony.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Enlightened Piano Radio Awards Ceremony and Concert|url = http://www.carnegiehall.org/Calendar/2015/10/24/0100/PM/Enlightened-Piano-Radio-Awards-Ceremony-and-Concert|website = www.carnegiehall.org|access-date = 2016-01-11}}</ref> [[Winter Symphony - Jennifer Thomas (pianist) album]] Thomas' fourth album was released in November 2015. Mixed by five time [[Grammy Award]] winner [[Brian Vibberts]], contributors included [[Glen Gabriel]], [[Ricky Kej]] and [[Taylor Davis (violinist)]]. Following the album release, Thomas performed concerts at [[Salt Lake City]], [[Atascocita, Texas]] and the [[Benaroya Hall]] [[Seattle]].<ref name="Sound Publishing Inc"/> The album has received many favorable reviews and during 2016 won several prestigious awards. In March 2017 Thomas arranged an orchestral cover of the [[Beauty and the Beast (Disney song)]] featuring cellist Armen Ksajikian to coincide with the release of the [[Walt Disney Pictures]] and [[Mandeville Films]] movie [[Beauty and the Beast (2017 film)]]. During July 2017 Thomas collaborated with [[poet]] J.ournal to produce a double award-winning track and video ''Nine Twelve'', a powerful [[9/11]] reminder message,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mormonmusic.org/artists/jennifer-thomas/jennifer-thomas-j-ournal-poems-nine-twelve-lest-forget|title=Jennifer Thomas and J.ournal Poems - "Nine Twelve, " Lest We Forget - Mormon Music|date=2017-07-03|work=Mormon Music|access-date=2017-07-09|language=en-US}}</ref> and in October 2017 she released a 10-year special re-mastered edition of her 2007 album 'Key of Sea'.
On 12 October 2018 Thomas widely released a ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' charting [[classical music|classical]]/[[cinematic music]] styled album titled 'The Fire Within' - which she previewed live in concert at [[Benaroya Hall]] in [[Seattle]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.peninsuladailynews.com/life/sequim-pianist-jennifer-thomas-finds-the-fire-within/|title=Sequim pianist Jennifer Thomas finds ‘The Fire Within’ {{!}} Peninsula Daily News|date=2018-07-06|work=Peninsula Daily News|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en-US}}</ref> In November 2018 a composition by Thomas, ''A Beautiful Storm'', was used in two winning [[ISU Grand Prix of Figure Skating]] gold medal programmes by [[Rika Kihira]] from [[Japan]]. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2018/11/25/figure-skating/rika-kihira-punches-ticket-grand-prix-final-second-gp-victory-season/|title=Rika Kihira punches ticket for Grand Prix Final with second GP victory of season|date=2018-11-25|work=The Japan Times Online|access-date=2018-11-29|language=en-US|issn=0447-5763}}</ref>
==Discography== '''Albums:''' * ''The Fire Within'' (2018) featuring [[Tina Guo]] <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mormonmusic.org/artists/jennifer-thomas/jennifer-thomas-new-masterpiece-the-fire-within/attachment/jennifer-thomas-the-fire-within|title=Jennifer Thomas - The Fire Within - Mormon Music|work=Mormon Music|access-date=2018-10-13|language=en-US}}</ref> *''Key of Sea (10 Year Special Edition)'' (2017)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/key-of-sea-10-year-special-edition/id1297071061|title=Key of Sea (10 Year Special Edition) by Jennifer Thomas on Apple Music|website=itunes.apple.com|access-date=2017-10-26}}</ref> *''Winter Symphony'' (2015).<ref>{{Cite web|title = iTunes Top New Christmas Albums|url = http://www.popvortex.com/music/charts/top-new-christmas-albums.php|website = PopVortex|publisher = |access-date = 2016-01-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Ensign Symphony & Chorus: Alleluia|url = http://www.seattlesymphony.org/concerttickets/calendar/2015-2016/concerts/benaroyahall/ensign-alleluia|website = www.seattlesymphony.org|access-date = 2016-01-11}}</ref> *''Illumination'' (2012)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/illumination/id545693307/|title=Illumination|work=iTunes|accessdate=2015-10-08}}</ref> *''The Lullaby Album, Vols 1 & 2'' (2009)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/lullaby-album-vol.-2-solo/id340747978|title=The Lullaby Album, Vol. 2 Solo Piano|work=iTunes|accessdate=2015-10-08}}</ref> *''Key of Sea'' (2007)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/key-of-sea/id218161398|title=Key of Sea|work=iTunes|accessdate=2015-10-08}}</ref>
Thomas also features on the following albums; * ''Spring of Fire'' (2018) - 92 Keys - Life and Death <ref>{{Citation|title=Spring of Fire by 92 Keys|date=2018-09-04|url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/album/spring-of-fire/1417208944|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref> *''Merry Christmas'' (2015) - [[:sv:Viktoria Tocca]] <ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://viktoriatocca.com/product/merry-christmas-pre-order/ |title=Merry Christmas |publisher= ''Viktoria Tocca'' |date=2015-10-09 |accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> *''Dream It'' (2015) - [[:sv:Viktoria Tocca]]<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://viktoriatocca.com/product/dream-it/ |title=Dream It |publisher=Viktoria Tocca |date=2015-10-09 |accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref> *''Love Language'' (Grammy nomination 2015) - [[Wouter Kellerman]].<ref>{{Cite web|title={{!}} GRAMMY.com |url=http://www.grammy.com/nominees |website=The GRAMMYs |access-date=2016-01-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141207032519/http://www.grammy.com/nominees |archivedate=2014-12-07 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lovelanguagemusic.com/ |title=Love Language |publisher=Lovelanguagemusic.com |date= |accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Wouter Kellerman - Love Language|url = http://www.mainlypiano.com/2015_Reviews/Kellerman-Love_Language.html|website = www.mainlypiano.com|access-date = 2016-01-11}}</ref> *''These Miles'' (2014) - [[Jonathan Estabrooks]] <ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://ottawacitizen.com/entertainment/music/jonathan-estabrooks-many-miles-on-this-albums-road |title=Jonathan Estabrooks: Many miles on this album’s road |publisher=Ottawa Citizen |date= |accessdate=2015-10-13}}</ref> *''Roads: The Many Miles Music Artists (2014) - ''Into the Forest''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00OMQX2YY |title=Roads: The Many Miles Music Artists: Various artists: MP3 Downloads |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2015-10-13}}</ref> *'' Best of the Swan Lake: 2007 Moving Image & Music Award (2007) - ''Fly Away'', ''Release'', ''The Tempest'' <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00160VLSI |title=Best of the Swan Lake: 2007 Moving Image & Music Award: Various artists: MP3 Downloads |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2015-10-13}}</ref>
==Film and TV== List: * 2018 [[Internationaux de France]] ice skating gold medal won by [[Rika Kihira]] to the programme of 'A Beautiful Storm' composed by Thomas * 2018 [[ NHK Trophy]] ice skating gold medal won by [[Rika Kihira]] to the programme of 'A Beautiful Storm' composed by Thomas * 2017 Film Score "Desert Rose" <ref>{{Citation|last=McNeal|first=Ryan K.|title=Desert Rose|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6611790/|others=Kate Cobb, Coty Galloway, Alexander Rupert Green|accessdate=2017-10-26}}</ref> * 2015 [[U.S. Figure Skating Championships]], [[Hannah Miller]], Short program <ref>{{cite web|url=http://figureskatersonline.com/hannahmiller/main/on-the-ice/ |title=On The Ice | Hannah Miller :: Official Web Site |publisher=Figureskatersonline.com |date=2014-06-20 |accessdate=2015-10-13}}</ref> * 2014 [[ISU Junior Grand Prix]], [[Zagreb]], [[Karen Chen]] <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.isuresults.com/events/cat00028158.htm|title=Entry/Resultlist|website=www.isuresults.com|access-date=2016-05-17}}</ref> * 2013 [[International Skating Union]], [[Angela Wang]] JGP Baltic Cup Junior Ladies Short program <ref>{{Cite web|title = Angela Wang|url = http://web.icenetwork.com/skaters/profile/angela_wang|website = icenetwork.com|access-date = 2016-01-11}}</ref> * 2013 "Running the Edge", directed by Matt Trappe, song placements<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trappephoto.com/coloradotrailfilm/|title=RUNNING THE EDGE|author=|date=|work=Matt Trappe Photo & Film|accessdate=2015-10-09}}</ref> * 2011 Film score "Minuet", directed and written by Ryan K. McNeal, score by Jennifer Thomas <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rkmstudios.org/RKM_Studios/RKM_Studios___Home.html |title=Home |publisher=RKM Studios |date= |accessdate=2015-10-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cHsVgVvISFk|title = Minuet Award-Winning Short Film|publisher = YouTube|date = 2012-08-13|accessdate = 2015-10-13}}</ref> * 2012 [[National Basketball Association]] Sports placements <ref>{{cite web|url=http://watch.nba.com/video/channels/nba_tv/2011/05/19/20110519_sounds_playoff2_d.nba |title=Watch Live NBA Games with NBA LEAGUE PASS from NBA.COM |publisher=Watch.nba.com |date= |accessdate=2015-10-13}}</ref> * 2012 [[NBC Universal]] Sports placements<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L3M785rVY14 |title=World Beach Volleyball Championships Promo - Jennifer Thomas "Fly Away" |publisher=YouTube |date=2015-09-04 |accessdate=2015-10-13}}</ref> * 2014 [[MGM]] [[Equal Justice (TV series)]] placements <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SM0iLPF6fYU |title=Equal Justice, Season 2, Ep. 11 - Featuring music by Jennifer Thomas |publisher=YouTube |date=2011-03-30 |accessdate=2015-10-13}}</ref> * 2008 "Reasons", Poor Boyz Productions<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.poorboyzstore.com/dvd/reasons|title=Reasons - Poor Boyz Productions Store|author=|date=|work=poorboyzstore.com|accessdate=2015-10-09}}</ref>
==Awards and nominations== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Category !! Work !! Result !! Microsoft Store |publisher=Microsoft.com |date= |accessdate=2015-10-13}}</ref> |}
==Early life== Thomas was born in [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]]. She got her first toy piano at the age of 3, and began formal lessons on both the piano and violin at the age of 5, under the tutelage of her mother, Carolyn Southworth.<ref name="jenniferthomasmusic.wordpress.com"/> Her brothers also learned piano, violin, and cello from their mother. Jennifer and her older brother played in grade school orchestras, with Southworth as a conductor's assistant. Thomas continued to train classically, and was involved in many recitals and piano adjudications through her teen years. She played with various youth orchestras and high school orchestras. She performed at her high school graduation, and later went to [[Brigham Young University-Idaho]].<ref name="jenniferthomasmusic.wordpress.com"/>
At [[Brigham Young University-Idaho]], Thomas studied piano under Professor Stephen Allen. She was a member of the university's Piano Ensemble group, accompanied the College choir and many vocal/instrumental students, as well as played violin in the university symphony. Thomas also competed in the University's Concerto Competition, where she took 2nd place performing the [[Piano Concerto No. 3 (Prokofiev)]].<ref name="jenniferthomasmusic.wordpress.com"/>
After college graduation, Thomas moved to [[Salt Lake City]], [[Utah]], and was a regular performer with the [[Temple Square]] Concert Series, and played violin in the [[Murray, Utah]] Symphony Orchestra. While performing with the Murray Symphony, Thomas was a featured soloist on the [[Edward MacDowell]] Piano Concerto No.2.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiemusicchannel.com/photo/macdowell-concerto-murray-symphony-2002 |title=MacDowell Concerto - Murray Symphony 2002 |publisher=Indie Music Channel |date=2012-05-01 |accessdate=2015-10-13}}</ref> She eventually moved to Northwest, where she performed as a violinist with the Oregon Pro Arte Chamber Orchestra, and worked for the [[Seattle Symphony]] in the Education Department. It was during her time working for the [[Seattle Symphony]] when she started composing her own original music.
==Personal life== Thomas is married to Will Thomas, an ultra-marathon competitor who, in 2015, competed in the 106 mile race [[Ultra-Trail du Mont-Blanc]] in France. Together, they have three children and reside in the [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]] area.<ref name="jenniferthomasmusic.wordpress.com"/>
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}

revision.comment: why would you pick an unreferenced, unidentified image out of the large selection of jousting depictions on commons?
revision.text:
{{Redirect|Joust}} {{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} [[File:Paulus Hector Mair Tjost fig2.jpg|thumb|440px|[[German Renaissance|Renaissance-era]] depiction of a joust in traditional or "high" armor, based on then-historical late medieval armour ([[Paulus Hector Mair]], ''de arte athletica'', 1540s)]]
'''Jousting''' is a martial game or ''[[hastilude]]'' between two horsemen wielding [[lance]]s with blunted tips, often as part of a [[tournament (medieval)|tournament]]. The primary aim was to replicate a clash of [[heavy cavalry]], with each participant trying hard to strike the opponent while riding towards him at high speed, if possible breaking the lance on the opponent's shield or [[jousting armour]], or unhorsing him. The joust became an iconic characteristic of the [[knight (stock character)|knight]] in Romantic [[medievalism]]. The participants experience close to three and a quarter times their body weight in G-forces when the lances collide with their armour.<ref>{{Cite episode |title=May The G Force Be With You |url=https://www.netflix.com/watch/80107437?trackId=14272744 |access-date=10 December 2016 |series=White Rabbit Project |first1=Kari |last1=Byron |author1-link=Kari Byron |first2=Grant |last2=Imahara |author2-link=Grant Imahara |first3=Tory |last3=Belleci |author3-link=Tory Belleci |network=[[Netflix]] |date=9 December 2016 |season=1 |number=6 |minutes=37 }}</ref>
The term is derived from [[Old French]] {{lang|fro|joster}}, ultimately from [[Latin]] {{lang|la|iuxtare}} "to approach, to meet". The word was loaned into [[Middle English]] around 1300, when jousting was a very popular sport among the [[Anglo-Normans|Anglo-Norman]] knighthood. The synonym '''tilt''' dates {{circa|1510}}.
Jousting is based on the military use of the lance by heavy cavalry. It transformed into a specialised sport during the [[Late Middle Ages]], and remained popular with the [[nobility]] in [[Tudor period|England and Wales]] and [[16th-century Germany|Germany]] throughout the whole of the 16th century (while in France, it was discontinued after the death of [[Henry II of France|King Henry II]] in an accident in 1559).<ref>{{cite book |last1=Barber |first1=Richard |first2=Juliet |last2=Barker |title=Tournaments: Jousts, Chivalry and Pageants in the Middle Ages |publisher=Boydell |date=1 January 1989 |pages=134, 139 |isbn=978-0-85115-470-1}}</ref> In England, jousting was the highlight of the [[Accession Day tilt]]s of [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth I]] and of [[James VI and I]], and also was part of the festivities at the marriage of [[Charles I of England|Charles I]].{{Sfn|Young|1977|pp=201–8}}
Jousting was discontinued in favour of other [[equestrian sports]] in the 17th century, although non-contact forms of "[[tent pegging|equestrian skill-at-arms]]" disciplines survived. There has been a limited revival of [[theatrical jousting]] re-enactment since the 1970s.
==Medieval joust== [[Image:Codex Manesse 081 Walther von Klingen.jpg|thumb|right|Depiction of a late 13th-century joust in the [[Codex Manesse]]. Joust by Walther von Klingen.]] The medieval joust has its origins in the military tactics of [[heavy cavalry]] during the [[High Middle Ages]]. By the 14th century, many members of the nobility, including kings had taken up jousting to showcase their own courage, skill and talents, and the sport proved just as dangerous for a king as a knight, and from the 15th century on, jousting became a sport (''[[hastilude]]'') without direct relevance to warfare.
===High Middle Ages=== From the 11th to 14th centuries when medieval jousting was still practised in connection to the use of the lance in warfare, armour evolved from [[mail (armour)|mail]] (with a solid, heavy helmet, called a "[[great helm]]", and shield) to plate armour. By 1400, knights wore full suits of [[plate armour]], called a "harness" (Clephan 28-29).
In this early period, a ''joust'' was still a (martial) "meeting", i.e. a [[duel]] in general and not limited to the lance. Combatants would begin riding on one another with the lance, but might continue with shorter range weapons after the distance was closed or after one or both parties had been unhorsed. Tournaments in the High Medieval period were much rougher and less "gentlemanly" affairs than in the late medieval era of [[chivalry]]. The rival parties would fight in groups, with the aim of incapacitating their adversaries for the sake of gaining their horses, arms and ransoms.<ref>L.F. Salzman, "English Life in the Middle Ages," Oxford, 1950. "These early tournaments were very rough affairs and in every sense, quite unlike the chivalrous contests of later days; the rival parties fought in groups, and it was considered not only fair but commendable to hold off until you saw some of your adversaries getting tired and then to join in the attack on them; the object was not to break a lance in the most approved style, but frankly to disable as many opponents as possible for the sake of obtaining their spears, arms, and ransoms." </ref>
===Late Middle Ages=== [[File:Sigstap rienolt tjost.jpg|thumb|Depiction of a standing joust in an Alsatian manuscript of ca. 1420 ([[CPG 359]]); protection for the legs of the riders is integrated into the horse armour.]] With the development of the courtly ideals of [[chivalry]] in the late medieval period, the joust became more regulated. This tendency is also reflected in the [[pas d'armes]] in general. It was now considered dishonourable to exploit an opponent's disadvantage, and knights would pay close attention to avoid being in a position of advantage, seeking to gain honour by fighting against the odds. This romanticised "chivalric revival" was based on the [[chivalric romance]]s of the high medieval period, which noblemen tried to "reenact" in real life, sometimes blurring the lines of reality and fiction.
The development of the term ''[[knight]]'' (''chevalier'') dates to this period. Before the 12th century, ''cniht'' was a term for a servant. In the 12th century, it became used of a military follower in particular. Also in the 12th century, a special class of noblemen serving in cavalry developed, known as ''milites nobiles''. By the end of the 13th century, ''chivalry'' (''chyualerye'') was used not just in the technical sense of "cavalry" but for martial virtue in general. It was only after 1300 that ''knighthood'' (''kniȝthod'', originally a term for "boyhood, youth") came to be used as a junior rank of nobility. By the later 14th century, the term became romanticised for the ideal of the young nobleman seeking to prove himself in honourable exploits, the [[knight-errant]], which among other things encompassed the [[pas d'armes]], including the joust. By the 15th century, "knightly" virtues were sought by the noble classes even of ranks much senior than "knight".<ref>[[OED]], s.v. "knight", "knighthood", "chivalry".</ref> The iconic association of the [[knight (stock character)|"knight" stock-character]] with the joust is thus historical, but develops only at the end of the Middle Ages.
The ''lists'', or ''list field'', was the arena where a jousting event was held. More precisely, it was the roped-off enclosure where tournament fighting took place.<ref name="Hopkins2004">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n0INlcK2NlgC&pg=PT36 | title=Tournaments and Jousts: Training for War in Medieval Times | publisher=The Rosen Publishing Group | last=Hopkins | first=Andrea | year=2004 | page=36 | isbn=978-0-8239-3994-7}}</ref> In the late medieval period, castles and palaces were augmented by purpose-built ''[[tiltyard]]s'' as a venue for "jousting tournaments". Training for such activities included the use of special equipment, of which the best-known was the [[Quintain (jousting)|quintain]].
The ''[[Froissart's Chronicles|Chronicles of Froissart]]'', written during the 1390s, and covering the period of 1327 to 1400, contain many details concerning jousting in this era. The combat was now expected to be non-lethal, and it was not necessary to incapacitate the opponent, who was expected to honourably yield to the dominant fighter. The combat was divided into rounds of three encounters with various weapons, of which the joust proper was one. During this time, the joust detached itself from the reality on the battlefield and became a chivalric sport. Knights would seek opportunities to duel opponents from the hostile camp for honour off the battlefield.
As an example, Froissart<ref>{{Citation |last = Froissart | first = John | title = Chronicles of England, France, Spain and the adjoining countries from the latter part of the reign of Edward II to the coronation of Henry IV in 12 volumes | edition = 1803–10 | url = http://www.medievalist.globalfolio.net/eng/f/ | volume = 1 | pages = 613–15 | publisher = Global folio}}</ref><ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.nipissingu.ca/department/history/muhlberger/froissart/gauvain.htm | title = Gauvain | publisher = Nipissingu | place = CA}}</ref> records that, during a campaign in [[Beauce, France|Beauce]] in the year 1380, a squire of the garrison of [[Toury]] castle named Gauvain Micaille (Michaille)—also mentioned in the ''Chronique du bon duc Loys de Bourbon'' as wounded in 1382 at [[Battle of Roosebeke|Roosebeke]], and again in 1386; in 1399 was in the service of the duke of Bourbon<ref>{{Citation | first = Siméon | last = Luce | title = Chroniques | year = 1869 | url = https://archive.org/stream/chroniques09froi#page/n118/mode/1up | page = cvii}}</ref>{{Sfn | Coltman | 1919 | p = 29}}—yelled out to the English, {{quote |Is there among you any gentleman who for the love of his lady is willing to try with me some feat of arms? If there should be any such, here I am, quite ready to sally forth completely armed and mounted, to tilt three courses with the lance, to give three blows with the battle axe, and three strokes with the dagger. Now look, you English, if there be none among you in love.}}
The challenge was answered by a squire named Joachim Cator, who said "I will deliver him from his vow: let him make haste and come out of the castle."
Micaille came to meet his opponent with attendants carrying three lances, three battle-axes, three swords and three daggers. The duel began with a joust, described as follows: {{quote |When they had taken their stations, they gave to each of them a spear, and the tilt began; but neither of them struck the other, from the mettlesomeness of their horses. They hit the second onset, but it was by darting their spears.<ref>Johnes, Thomas. ''Sir John Froissart's Chronicles of England'', 208</ref>}} The meeting was then adjourned, and continued on the next day.
{{quote |They met each other roughly with spears, and the French squire tilted much to the satisfaction of the earl: but the Englishman kept his spear too low, and at last struck it into the thigh of the Frenchman. The earl of Buckingham as well as the other lords were much enraged by this, and said it was tilting dishonorably; but he excused himself, by declaring it as solely owing to the restiveness of his horse.<ref>https://faculty.nipissingu.ca/muhlberger/FROISSART/GAUVAIN.HTM</ref>}}
In spite of the French squire's injury, the duel was continued with three thrusts with the sword. After this, the encounter was stopped because of the Micaille's loss of blood. He was given leave to rejoin his garrison with a reward of a hundred francs by the earl of Buckingham, who stated that he had acquitted himself much to his satisfaction.
Froissart describes a tournament at Cambray in 1385, held on the marriage of the Count d'Ostrevant to the daughter of Duke Philip of Burgundy. The tournament was held in the market-place of the town, and forty knights took part. The king jousted with a knight of [[Hainaut (province)|Hainault]], Sir John Destrenne, for the prize of a clasp of precious stones, taken off from the bosom of the Duchess of Burgundy; it was won by Sir Destrenne, and formally presented by the [[Admiral of France]] and Sir Guy de la Trimouille.
A knightly duel in this period usually consisted in three courses of jousting, and three blows and strokes exchanged with battle-axes, swords, and daggers. This number tended to be extended towards the end of the century, until the most common number was five, as in the duel between Sir Thomas Harpenden and Messire Jean des Barres, at Montereau sur Yonne in 1387 (''cinq lances a cheval, cinq coups d'épée, cinq coups de dague et cinq coups de hache''). Later could be as high as ten or even twelve. In the 1387 encounter, the first four courses of the joust were run without decisive outcome, but in the fifth Sir Thomas was unhorsed and lost consciousness. He was revived, however, and all the strokes and blows could be duly exchanged, without any further injury.
On another instance, a meeting with sharp lances was arranged to take place near [[Nantes]], under the auspices of the [[Grand Constable of France|Constable of France]] and the Earl of Buckingham. The first encounter was a combat on foot, with sharp spears, in which one of the cavaliers was slightly wounded; the pair then ran three courses with the lance without further mishap. Next Sir John Ambreticourt of Hainault and Sir Tristram de la Jaille of [[Poitou]] advanced from the ranks and jousted three courses, without hurt. A duel followed between Edward Beauchamp, son of Sir Robert Beauchamp, and the bastard Clarius de Savoye. Clarius was much the stronger man of the two, and Beauchamp was unhorsed. The bastard then offered to fight another English champion, and an esquire named Jannequin Finchly came forward in answer to the call; the combat with swords and lances was very violent, but neither of the parties was hurt.
Another encounter took place between John de Chatelmorant and Jannequin Clinton, in which the Englishman was unhorsed. Finally Chatelmorant fought with Sir William Farrington, the former receiving a dangerous wound in the thigh, for which the Englishman was greatly blamed, as being an infraction of the rules of the tourney, but an accident was pleaded just as in the case of the 1380 duel between Gauvain Micaille and Joachim Cator.<ref>{{Harvnb | Coltman | 1919 | p = 30}} summarizing {{Citation |title = Froissart's Chronicles | chapter = 5 | page = 47}}</ref>
==Renaissance-era joust== {{further|Plate armour}} The medieval joust took place on an open field. Indeed, the term ''joust'' meant "a meeting" and referred to arranged combat in general, not just the jousting with lances. At some point in the 14th century, a cloth barrier was introduced as an option to separate the contestants. This barrier was presumably known as ''tilt'' in Middle English (a term with an original meaning of "a cloth covering"). It became a wooden barrier or fence in the 15th century, now known as "tilt barrier", and "tilt" came to be used as a term for the joust itself by {{circa|1510}}. The purpose of the tilt barrier was to prevent collisions and to keep the combatants at an optimal angle for breaking the lance. This greatly facilitated the control of the horse and allowed the rider to concentrate on aiming the lance. The introduction of the barrier seems to have originated in the south, as it only became a standard feature of jousting in Germany in the 16th century, and was there called the Italian or "{{lang|gmh|[[walhaz|welsch]]}}" mode.<ref>{{cite book |first=Braden K. |last=Frieder |title=Chivalry & The Perfect Prince: Tournaments, Art, and Armor at the Spanish Habsburg Court |publisher= Truman State University Press |year= 2008 |isbn= 978-1-931112-69-7 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=NFtMbrAHZpsC&pg=PA7 |page=7f }}</ref> Dedicated [[tilt-yards]] with such barriers were built in England from the time of [[Henry VIII]].
[[File:KHM Wien S XVI - Jousting armour of John the Constant, c. 1497-1505, front.jpg|thumb|The ''{{lang|de|Stechzeug}}'' of [[John the Constant]] ({{circa|1500}})]] Specialised jousting armour was produced in the late 15th to 16th century. It was heavier than suits of [[plate armour]] intended for combat, and could weigh as much as 50 kg (110 lb), compared to some 25 kg (55 lb) for field armour; as it did not need to permit free movement of the wearer, the only limiting factor was the maximum weight that could be carried by a [[warhorse]] of the period.<ref>{{cite book |first1=David |last1=Edge |first2=John Miles |last2=Paddock |title=Arms & armor of the medieval knight |publisher= Crescent Books|year= 1988 |isbn= 978-0-517-64468-3|page=162}}</ref>
During the 1490s, emperor [[Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor|Maximilian I]] invested a lot of effort into perfecting the sport, for which he received his nickname of "The Last Knight". ''{{lang|de|Rennen}}'' and ''{{lang|de|Stechen}}'' were two sportive forms of the joust developed during the 15th century and practised throughout the 16th century. The armours used for these two respective styles of the joust was known as ''{{lang|de|Rennzeug}}'' and ''{{lang|de|Stechzeug}}'', respectively.The ''{{lang|de|Stechzeug}}'' in particular developed into extremely heavy armour which completely inhibited the movement of the rider, in its latest forms resembling an armour-shaped cabin integrated into the [[horse armour]] more than a functional suit of armour. Such forms of sportive equipment during the final phase of the joust in [[16th-century Germany]] gave rise to modern misconceptions about the heaviness or clumsiness of "medieval armour", as notably popularised by [[Mark Twain]]'s ''[[A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court]]''.<ref>{{cite book |last=Ellis |first=John |title=Cavalry: The History of Mounted Warfare |publisher=[[Putnam, Connecticut|Putnam]] |year=1978 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Woosnam-Savage |first=Robert C |author2=Anthony Hall |title=Brassey's Book of Body Armor |publisher=Potomac Books |year=2002 |isbn=1-57488-465-4}}</ref> The extremely heavy helmets of the ''{{lang|de|Stechzeug}}'' are explained by the fact that the aim was to detach the [[crest (heraldry)|crest]] of the opponent's helmet, resulting in frequent full impact of the lance to the helmet.
By contrast the ''{{lang|de|Rennen}}'' was a type of joust with lighter contact. Here, the aim was to hit the opponent's shield. The specialised ''{{lang|de|Rennzeug}}'' was developed on the request of Maximilian, who desired a return to a more agile form of joust compared to the heavily armoured "full contact" ''{{lang|de|Stechen}}''. In the ''{{lang|de|Rennzeug}}'', the shield was attached to the armour with a mechanism of springs and would detach itself upon contact.
In France, the 1559 death of King [[Henry II of France|Henry II]] of wounds suffered in a tournament led to the end of jousting as a sport.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Graham |last=Martin |title=The death of Henry II of France: A sporting death and post-mortem. |journal=ANZ Journal of Surgery |volume=71 |issue=5 |pages=318–20 |date=May 2001 }}</ref>
The tilt continued through Henry VIII and onto the reign of Elizabeth I. Under her rule, tournaments were seen as more of a parade or show than an actual martial exercise.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Schulze |first=Ivan L. |year=1933 |title=Notes on Elizabethan Chivalry and "The Faerie Queene" |jstor=4172200 |journal=Studies in Philology |volume=30 |pages=148–159 }}</ref>
The last Elizabethan [[Accession Day tilt]] was held in November 1602; Elizabeth died the following spring. Tilts continued as part of festivities marking the Accession Day of [[James I of England|James I]], 24 March, until 1624, the year before his death.{{Sfn|Strong|1977|pp=137–38}}{{Sfn|Young|1987|p=208}} In the early 17th century, the joust was replaced as the equine highlight of court festivities by large "horse-ballet" displays called [[carousel]]s, although non-combat competitions such as the ring-tilt lasted until the 18th century.
One attempt to revive the joust was the [[Eglinton Tournament of 1839]].
<gallery widths="220px" heights="220px" perrow="4"> File:Armor of Emperor Ferdinand I (1503–1564) MET DT773.jpg|[[Armor of Ferdinand I, Holy Roman Emperor]], 1549 File:Armor of Henry II, King of France (reigned 1547–59) MET DP256960.jpg|[[Parade Armour of Henry II of France]], c. 1553-55 File:Henry VIII armor by Matthew Bisanz.JPG|Armour for King Henry VIII by Matthew Bisanz, 1544 File:Tower of london 812.jpg|Armour worn by King Henry VIII </gallery>
==Horses== {{further|Horses in the Middle Ages|Horses in warfare}} The two most common kinds of horse used for jousting were [[warmblood]] ''[[Horses in the Middle Ages|charger]]s'' and larger ''[[destrier]]s''. Chargers were medium-weight horses bred and trained for agility and stamina. Destriers were heavier, similar to today's [[Andalusian horse]], but not as large as the modern [[draft horse]].
During a jousting tournament, the horses were cared for by their [[groom (horses)|groom]]s in their respective tents. They wore [[caparison]]s, a type of ornamental cloth featuring the owner's [[heraldry|heraldic signs]]. Competing horses had their heads protected by a [[chanfron]], an iron shield for protection from otherwise lethal lance hits (Clayton 22-56).
Other forms of equipment on the horse included long-necked [[spur]]s which enabled the rider to control the horse with extended legs, a [[saddle]] with a high back to provide leverage during the charge or when hit, as well as [[stirrup]]s for the necessary leverage to deliver blows with the lance (Tkačenko).
==Modern revivals== ===Modern day jousting=== [[File:Jousting at Middelaldercentret2.jpg|thumb|Jousting at [[Middelaldercentret]]]] {{main|Theatrical jousting}}
[[Jousting reenactment|Jousting re-enactors]] have been active since the 1970s. A jousting show took place in 1972 at the Principality of Gwrych in [[North Wales]] near [[Abergele]]. The Company of Knights Limited, founded in early 1974, organised jousting shows including from five to as many as fifty actors.
Between 1980 and 1982 the Little England theme park in [[Orlando, Florida]] was planned as a jousting stadium. Although the first phase of the project was constructed, high interest rates cancelled the project. The medieval dinner re-enactment company [[Medieval Times]] includes the sport in its dinner show. Jousting shows are also offered seasonally at [[Warwick Castle]] and [[Hever Castle]] in the United Kingdom. And groups like the Knights of Royal England travel around Britain and Europe staging medieval Jousting Tournaments; at the Danish museum [[Middelaldercentret]] there are daily tournaments during the season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hrp.org.uk/NewsAndMedia/Pressresources/NewsAndMediaPressresourcesTOLTournamentattheTower |title=Historic Royal Palaces > Home > Hidden > Press releases 2006-2008 > Tournament at the Tower |publisher=Hrp.org.uk |accessdate=2014-04-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228080515/http://www.hrp.org.uk/NewsAndMedia/Pressresources/NewsAndMediaPressresourcesTOLTournamentattheTower |archivedate=28 December 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://middelaldercentret.dk/Events/ridderturneringe.html |title=Ridderturneringer |publisher=Middelaldercentret.dk |accessdate=2014-04-09}}</ref>
Jousting exhibitions are also sometimes featured in [[Renaissance fair]]s or other historical markets.
<gallery widths="220px" heights="220px" perrow="3"> File:Tournament between Henry II and Lorges.jpg|Tournament between Henry II and Lorges, 16th century Image:Broken lances.jpg|Broken lances at a joust at [[Bristol Renaissance Faire]], 2006 Image:Modern-Knight.jpg|Renaissance Fair jousting in [[Livermore, California]], 2006 File:Tilting - Knights of Royal England.jpg|thumb|Two knights from The Knights of Royal England tilting File:Knights of Royal England - Sir Jasper v Sir Samuel of Hever at Linlithgow Palace.jpg|thumb|Jousting Tournament at Linlithgow Palace in 2008 </gallery>
===Competitive jousting=== ''The Knights of Valour'' was a theatrical jousting group formed by [[Shane Adams]] in 1993. Members of this group began to practice jousting competitively, and their first tournament was held in 1997. Adams founded the World Championship Jousting Association (WCJA) as a body dedicated to jousting as a [[combat sport]], which held its inaugural tournament in [[Port Elgin, Ontario]] on 24 July 1999.<ref>{{cite web |author=ICE: Webmaster |url=http://www.aemma.org/training/mounted/mountedTraining.htm |title=Mounted Training at AEMMA |publisher=Aemma.org |accessdate=2014-04-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120615191607/http://www.aemma.org/training/mounted/mountedTraining.htm |archive-date=15 June 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Dashka |last=Slater |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/11/magazine/11Jousting-t.html |title=Is Jousting the Next Extreme Sport? |newspaper=New York Times |date= 8 July 2010}}</ref> The sport is presented in the 2012 television show ''[[Full Metal Jousting]]'', hosted by Adams. The rules are inspired by ''Realgestech'' (also ''Plankengestech''), one of the forms of ''stechen'' practised in 16th-century Germany, where reinforcing pieces were added to the [[jousting armour]] to serve as designated target areas. Instead of using a shield, the jousters aim for such a reinforcing piece added to the armour's left shoulder known as ''[[:de:Brechschild|Brechschild]]'' (also ''Stechtartsche''). A number of Jousting events are held regularly in Europe, some organised by [[Arne Koets]], including The Grand Tournament of Sankt Wendel and The Grand Tournament at [[Schaffhausen]].<ref>"An Interview with Arne Koets, jouster" The Jousting Life, December 2014</ref> Koets is one of a number of Jousters that travels internationally to events.

[[File:LUMA Foundation logo.jpeg|right|thumb|150px|]]
'''LUMA Foundation''' is a [[nonprofit organization]] established in 2004 that is based out of [[Zurich]] Switzerland. It supports the activities of independent [[contemporary art]]ists and other pioneers working in the fields of art, [[photography]], publishing, documentary, and [[multimedia]].
==History== Established by [[Maja Hoffmann]], the foundation promotes artistic projects combining a particular interest in [[Natural environment|environment]]al issues, [[human rights]], education,<ref>[http://www.bard.edu/ccs/exhibitions/luma-foundation-arles-summer-2011/] LUMA FOUNDATION</ref> and culture in the broadest sense.<ref>[http://www.dutch-doc.nl/docupedia/luma+foundation] LUMA Foundation information</ref>
==Programs== In 2011, the LUMA Foundation launched an acquisition program of books and films for its future library and hosted a symposium in [[Arles]] entitled The Human Snapshot, which brought together a number of leading thinkers to discuss the [[photographic]] image and its impact on [[human rights]].
The LUMA Foundation's focus is to create an experimental cultural complex, the Parc des Ateliers in [[Arles, France]],<ref>[http://www.e-flux.com/announcements/summer-program/] The LUMA Foundation in Arles 2013</ref> dedicated to the production of exhibitions and ideas and developed with architect [[Frank Gehry]]. <ref>[http://www.lemonde.fr/culture/article/2013/07/01/face-a-la-fondation-luma-les-rencontres-se-cherchent-un-espace-perenne_3439295_3246.html] Face à la Fondation Luma, les Rencontres se cherchent un espace pérenne</ref><ref>[http://provenceventouxblog.com/2013/frank-gehry-in-arles-watershed-moment-arrives-for-ultra-modish-tower-final-presentation-made-by-maja-hoffmann-of-luma-foundation/] Frank Gehry in Arles: Watershed Moment Arrives for Ultra Modish Tower; Final Presentation Made by Maja Hoffmann of Luma Foundation</ref> This project envisions an [[interdisciplinary]] center for the production of art exhibitions, research, education and archives. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://luma-arles.org/solaris-chronicles/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416180749/http://luma-arles.org/solaris-chronicles/ |archivedate=2014-04-16 |df= }} Solaris Chronicles</ref>
POOL is an innovative program that combines the collaboration of an international group of [[private collection|private collectors]] with a mentor-based training programme for [[art curator]]s. The programme has been conceived by [[Beatrix Ruf]], (Director and Curator, [[Kunsthalle]] [[Zürich]] 2001-2014) in collaboration with the founding collectors [[Maja Hoffmann]] and [[Michael Ringier]].<ref>[http://www.artprivee.org/directory/europe/switzerland/zurich/westbau-the-luma-foundation/] Private Museum Description</ref>
==LUMA Arles== LUMA [[Arles]], which launched formally in 2013, is dedicated to providing artists with opportunities to experiment in the production of new work through interdisciplinary collaboration. The conceptualisation of its mission, and the initial programming, has been spearheaded by [[Maja Hoffmann]]. LUMA Arles is an institution dedicated to providing artists with opportunities to experiment in the production and presentation of new work in close collaboration with other [[artists]], [[curators]], [[scientists]], [[innovators]] and [[audiences]]. The centrepiece of the 20-acre LUMA Arles campus is a new Arts Resource Centre building designed by [[Frank Gehry]] to house research and reference facilities, workshop and seminar rooms, and artist studios and presentation spaces.<ref>[http://www.loeildelaphotographie.com/2014/04/08/events/24624/arles-a-historic-weekend] Arles, A Historic Weekend France by Jean-Jacques Naudet</ref> LUMA Arles also encompasses six historic, large-scale industrial buildings. One historic building, the Grande Halle, was renovated in 2007 by the initiative of the [[Provence-Alpes-Côte d’Azur]] region.
LUMA Arles works in collaboration with Actes Sud, a major French publishing house known for its work in the arts, humanities, and for children, and the École Nationale Supérieure de la Photographie, the first post-graduate program to specialise in photography in [[France]]. Every summer, LUMA Arles hosts installations and programs for the international photography festival, [[Rencontres d’Arles]].
==Collaborators== The Foundation engages in long-term collaborations with institutions like the [[New Museum of Contemporary Art]] (New York), CCS [[Bard College]] (Annandale-on-Hudson, New York), [[Serpentine Gallery]] and [[Tate Modern]] (London), the [[Kunsthalle Zürich]] and the [[Fotomuseum Winterthur]] (Switzerland). LUMA is a partner of Les Rencontres d’Arles Photographie Awards in [[Arles]].
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://vimeo.com/user19468596] LUMA Foundation video documentation * [http://www.artprivee.org/directory/europe/switzerland/zurich/westbau-the-luma-foundation/] LUMA Foundation

{{italic title}} '''''La nobla leyczon''''' ({{IPA-oc|la ˈnɔbːlɔ lejˈsu|oc}}, ''La nòbla leiçon'' in modern [[Occitan language|Occitan]], "The Noble Lesson") is an anonymous text written in [[Old Occitan]]. It is the founding documentThe most important of the Waldensian literature is a poem in Provençal, ''La Nobla Leyczon'', but it is not entirely original, having been edited.[http://www.askwhy.co.uk/christianheresy/0811Inquisition.php] of the [[Waldensians|Waldensian]] creed. Its sixth line, ''ben ha mil & cent an complí entierament'' (already eleven hundred years have run their course [since [[Christ]] died]), places it in the early 12th century but modern scholars now date it between 1190 and 1240.Bosio, Enrico: La Nobla Leyczon ''considérée au point de vue de la doctrine, de la morale et de l'histoire'', Bulletin de la Société d'Histoire Vaudoise, n° 2 (dic. 1885), pp. 20-36. However, the very same line varies according to which of the four manuscripts is studied: the [[Geneva]] and [[Dublin]] ones say ''mil e cen'' (1100) while the [[Cambridge]] ones both state ''mil e cccc cent'' (1400).Édouard Montet, ''La noble leçon, texte original d'après le manuscrit de Cambridge'', 1888, p. 4. Further discrepancies include various anachronisms and the fact that Old Occitan was not spoken in the [[Lyon]] region.Judith Collins, ''Heritage of the Waldensians: a Sketch'', WRS Journal 3:2 (August 1996) 9-15, p.2: This pre-dates Peter of Lyons, who with his followers, were chased from Lyons about 1186, when they joined the valley dwellers, the Valdese. [...] The ''Lesson'' mentions the Vaudois (''Valdense'') as being already persecuted and as having already a well-known history. The idiom of the ''Nobla Leyczon'' is that of the valleys, the Romance language, and not that of the idiom of Lyons, a French dialect, which it would have been if Peter (''Valdo'') and his Poor Men had authored it.[http://www.wrs.edu/Materials_for_Web_Site/Journals/3-2%20Aug-1996/Collins%20-%20Waldensians.pdf] The manuscript was found in the [[Piedmont]]ese valleys.Ralph Griffiths & George Edward Griffiths, ''The Monthly Review'', 1825, p. 259 [https://books.google.com/books?id=KfhGYUVvr6EC&pg=PA259&dq=noble+lesson&hl=en&ei=jZ9eTOaRB8Ge4AaY85i5Ag&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CD8Q6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=noble%20lesson&f=false] The 479 lines of the poem can be divided into seven parts according to the themes treated [http://www.info-bible.org/livres/Histoire.Eglise.Vaudoise.2/13.htm#repentance]: 1-56 deal with the [[eschatology|end of the world]]; 57-229 retrace the history of the [[Bible]]; 230-265 tell of the new law; 266-333 narrate Jesus's life and works; 334-360 praise the faithful [[Christian Church]]; 361-413 relate the persecutions and the corrupted lives of [[papist]]s and 414-479 explain what true [[repentance]] is. ==Opening lines== {| |- | ''AYCÍ COMENCZA LA NOBLA LEYCZON ''O frayre, entendé ma nobla leyczon:
''Sovent devén velhar e istar en oracion,
''Car nos veén aquest mont esser pres del chavon;
''Mot curiós deoriàn ésser de bonas obras far,
''Car nos veén aquest mont de la fin apropiar.
''Ben ha mil & cent ancz complí entierament,
''Que fo scripta l'ora, car sen al derier temp.
''Poc deoriàn cubitar, car sen al remanent.
''Tot jorn veén las ensegnas venir a compliment,
''En acreysament de mal e en amermament de ben.
''Ayczó son li perilh que l'escriptura di:
''L'avangeli ho recoynta, e sant Paul atresí,
''Que neún home que viva, non po saber la fin.
''Enperczó devén mays temer, car nos non sen certan,
''Si la mort nos penré enchoy o deman.'' ||| THUS BEGINTH THE NOBLE LESSON [https://books.google.com/books?id=CHwFAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA287&dq=noble+lesson&hl=en&ei=jZ9eTOaRB8Ge4AaY85i5Ag&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFkQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q&f=false] O Brethren, give ear to a noble Lesson,
We ought always to watch and pray,
For we see this world nigh to a conclusion,
We ought to strive to do good works,
Seeing that the end of this world approacheth.
There are already a thousand and one hundred years fully accomplished
Since it was written thus, ''For we are in the last time''.
We ought to covet little, for we are at the latter end.
We see daily the signs to be accomplished
In the increase of evil and the decrease of good.
These are the perils which the Scripture mentioneth
In the Gospels and Saint Paul's writings.
No man living can know the end.
And therefore we ought the more to fear, for we are not certain
Whether we shall die to day or to morrow. |} ==External links== *[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5401134d.image.f37.pagination Full online text] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110913055752/http://www.oikoumene.org/gr/member-churches/regions/europe/italy/waldensian-church.html World Council of Churches] ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:La Nobla Leyczon}} [[Category:Occitan literature]] [[Category:Medieval literature]] [[Category:Christian denominations established in the 12th century]]

revision.text: {{see also|List of Dungeons & Dragons modules|List of Dungeons & Dragons adventures}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Dungeons & Dragons'' rulebooks}} This is a '''list of ''Dungeons & Dragons'' rulebooks''' for the ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' (''D&D'') [[fantasy]] [[role-playing game]], sorted by the edition of the game that they appeared in. This list does not include books designed for use as premade [[adventure (Dungeons & Dragons)|adventures]]. {{inc-lit}} ==Original ''Dungeons & Dragons''== {| class="wikitable" border="1" style="margins:auto; width=95%; font-size: 95%;" |- !width="30%"| Title !width="30%"| Authors !width="10%"| Date !width="30%"| Pages {{Book list | title = ''[[Dungeons & Dragons (1974)|Dungeons & Dragons]]'' | author = [[Gary Gygax]], [[Dave Arneson]] | aux1 = 3 booklets, 112 total (36, 40, 36) | publish_date = 1974 | short_summary = The original ''Dungeons & Dragons'' was published as a boxed set containing three separate booklets: * ''Volume 1: Men & Magic'' * ''Volume 2: Monsters & Treasure'' * ''Volume 3: Underworld & Wilderness Adventures'' This original version of ''D&D'' only included a few of the elements considered core to modern ''D&D'' and required the player to own several other games in order to make full use of the rules, however it is considered the first of what is now considered role-playing games and, along with its supplements, is responsible for the creation of the genre itself. }} {{Book list | title = ''[[Greyhawk (supplement)|Greyhawk]]'' | author = [[Gary Gygax]], [[Robert J. Kuntz]] | publish_date = 1975 | aux1 = 68 | short_summary = The first supplement for the original ''D&D'' game, ''Greyhawk'' focused primarily on rules and removed the game's dependence on the ''[[Chainmail (game)|Chainmail]]'' rules. Despite the name, the ''Greyhawk'' supplement was not intended as a setting supplement, but rather featured rules used in Gary Gygax's [[Greyhawk]] campaign.{{Cite news | last = Pulsipher | first = Lewis | authorlink = Lewis Pulsipher | date= February–March 1981 | title = An Introduction to Dungeons & Dragons | periodical = [[White Dwarf (magazine)|White Dwarf]] | place = London, England | publisher = [[Games Workshop]] | publication-date = February–March 1981 | issue = 23 | pages = 8–9 | postscript = }} }} {{Book list | title = ''[[Blackmoor (supplement)|Blackmoor]]'' | author = [[Dave Arneson]] | publish_date = 1975 | aux1 = 60 | short_summary = The second supplement for the original ''D&D'' game, ''Blackmoor'' added rules, monsters, treasure and is notable for containing the first published adventure for a role-playing game - "Temple of the Frog". Like ''Greyhawk'', its focus was more on rules than setting material, despite the name.[http://www.rpg.net/reviews/archive/12/12622.phtml Review of Dungeons & Dragons Supplement II: Blackmoor], Scott Casper (2006), retrieved March 2008 }} {{Book list | title = ''[[Eldritch Wizardry]]'' | author = [[Gary Gygax]], [[Brian Blume]] | publish_date = 1976 | aux1 = 60 | isbn = | short_summary = ''Eldritch Wizardry'' was the third supplement for the original ''D&D'' game and is most notable for introducing some of its most famous monsters, such as [[Demon (Dungeons & Dragons)|demons]] and [[Illithid|mind flayers]].{{cite web| url = http://www.acaeum.com/ddindexes/setpages/supplements.html | title = Original D&D Supplements | accessdate = 2009-01-17| publisher = The Acaeum}} }} {{Book list | title = ''[[Gods, Demi-Gods & Heroes]]'' | author = [[Robert J. Kuntz|Robert Kuntz]], [[Jim Ward (game designer)|James M. Ward]] | publish_date = 1976 | aux1 = 72 | isbn = | short_summary = ''Gods, Demi-Gods & Heroes'' was the fourth supplement for the original ''D&D'' game and adapted a variety of real-world and fictional pantheons for use in the ''D&D'' game. }} {{Book list | title = ''[[Swords & Spells]]'' | author = [[Gary Gygax]] | publish_date = 1976 | aux1 = 45 | isbn = | short_summary = The fifth and final supplement for the original ''D&D'' game focused on providing a new diceless set of rules for large battles between armies. ''Gods, Demi-Gods & Heroes'' stated itself to be the "last supplement"Kuntz & Ward. ''Gods, Demi-Gods, & Heroes'', Foreword. TSR Rules, 1976. for ''D&D'' in its introduction, and ''Swords & Spells'' did not have the official "Supplement V" designation on the cover. }} |} ==''Basic Dungeons & Dragons''== The ''[[Dungeons & Dragons Basic Set]]'' was the successor to original ''Dungeons & Dragons'' and was released while [[TSR, Inc.]] was working on the ''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons'' set. This set was the beginning of the split into two separate games, driven by disagreements on the direction the game should take. The Basic set retained the simplicity and flexibility of the original game while [[Gary Gygax]] took ''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons'' in a more structured and complicated direction.{{cite web| url = http://www.acaeum.com/ddindexes/setpages/basic.html| title = ''Acaeum: Basic Set''| accessdate = 2010-08-19| publisher = Acaeum| archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.acaeum.com%2Fddindexes%2Fsetpages%2Fbasic.html&date=2010-08-19| archivedate = 2010-08-19}} Initially it was expected that players would start using Basic edition and then graduate to ''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons''.Gygax & Arneson (1977) p. 6. states "...experience levels that high are not discussed in this book and the reader is referred to the more complete rules in ADVANCED DUNGEONS & DRAGONS" However, in 1981 the ''Basic Set'' underwent a complete revision and not long after this the ''Expert Set'' was released for the first time. All references to a progression from the ''Basic Set'' to ''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons'' were removed from the games and supplements as [[TSR, Inc.]] made clear that the expected progression was from the Basic Set to the Expert Set. From this point the ''D&D'' dichotomy became fixed and the ''Basic/Expert'' pair were considered a completely separate game from ''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons''.{{cite web| url = http://www.acaeum.com/ddindexes/setpages/expert.html| title = ''Acaeum: Expert Set''| accessdate = 2010-08-19| publisher = Acaeum| archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.acaeum.com%2Fddindexes%2Fsetpages%2Fexpert.html&date=2010-08-19| archivedate = 2010-08-19}} ;Core products {| class="wikitable sortable" Heard]] | style="text-align:center" | {{dts|1993}} | style="text-align:center" | Boxed set | style="text-align:center" | | style="text-align:center" | - |} ==''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons''== ''[[Advanced Dungeons & Dragons]]'' (''AD&D'') greatly expanded upon the rules and settings of the original ''D&D'' game when it was released in 1977. As such, this edition saw the publication of numerous books to assist players. The naming of the core books in this edition became the standard for all later editions. Around 1983, books such as ''MM'', ''PHB'', ''DMG'' and ''DDG'', all previous hardcover releases except ''Fiend Folio'', were upgraded with new cover art and unified in "orange spine" look. This included only minimal text change such as removal of rape references in ''DMG'' (books are now labeled "ages 10 and up"). ''MM2'' and the rest of the series followed the same format. By the end of its first decade, ''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons'' line had expanded to a library of 14 hardcover rulebooks, including three books of monsters, and two books governing character skills in wilderness and underground settings. ;Hardcovers {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margins:auto; width=95%; font-size: 95%;" |- !width="30%"| Title !width="30%"| Authors !width="10%"| Date !width="15%"| Pages !width="15%"| ISBN |- | ''[[Monster Manual#Original Monster Manual|Monster Manual]]'' | style="text-align:center" | [[Gary Gygax]] | style="text-align:center" | {{dts|1977-09}} | style="text-align:center" | 108 | style="text-align:center" | {{ISBNT|0-935696-00-8}} |- | ''[[Player's Handbook#Advanced Dungeons & Dragons|Player's Handbook]]'' | style="text-align:center" | [[Gary Gygax]], [[Mike Carr (game designer)|Mike Carr]] (editor) | style="text-align:center" | {{dts|1978-06}} | style="text-align:center" | 128 | style="text-align:center" | {{ISBNT|0-935696-01-6}} |- | ''[[Dungeon Master's Guide#Advanced Dungeons & Dragons|Dungeon Master's Guide]]'' | style="text-align:center" | [[Gary Gygax]] | style="text-align:center" | {{dts|1979-05}} | style="text-align:center" | 232 (1st-5th printings), 238 (subsequent printings). | style="text-align:center" | {{ISBNT|0-9356-9602-4}} |- | ''[[Deities & Demigods#1st Edition Advanced Dungeons & Dragons|Deities & Demigods]]'' | style="text-align:center" | [[Jim Ward (game designer)|James Ward]], [[Robert J. Initially, the second edition would consolidate the game, with two essential hardcovers and a 3-ring monster document binder that [[Dungeon Master]]s can sort contents as they wish. Periodically, [[TSR (company)|TSR]] published 3 lines of optional rulebooks (PHBR/DMGR/HR) and additional monster compendium to enhance game play. However, by popular demand TSR released a hardcover monster book in 1993. Also by 1995, with [[Glossary of video game terms#Power creep|power creep]] from optional classes and races becoming prominent, they were forced to abandon their original plan and revise the entire line.''[[30 Years of Adventure|30 Years of Adventure: A Celebration of Dungeons & Dragons]]'', Wizards of the Coast, 2004, {{ISBN|0-7869-3498-0}} pp.171-175 Core rules were rewritten, reorganized and accompanied with new logo, new art and black bordered cover style but had only a few meaningful rule changes. As the Basic game had been discontinued some years earlier, and the more straightforward title was more marketable, the word "Advanced" was dropped and the new edition was called just ''Dungeons & Dragons'', but was still officially referred to as [[Dungeons & Dragons 3rd edition|3rd edition]] (or 3E for short). This edition was the first to be released by [[Wizards of the Coast]] after their acquisition of the company, as well as the first to allow third-party companies to make supplemental materials by use of the [[Open Game License]]. A series of [[Map Folio]]s were also produced. In July 2003, a revised version of the 3rd edition ''D&D'' rules (termed [[Dungeons & Dragons version 3.5|version 3.5]]) was released that incorporated numerous rule changes, as well as expanding the ''Dungeon Master's Guide and Monster Manual''. ;Core rulebooks {| class="wikitable" border="1" style="margins:auto; Suleiman | publish_date = October 20, 2005 | isbn = 978-0-7869-3699-1 | aux1 = 160 | short_summary = ''[[Heroes of Horror]]'' provides everything players and [[Dungeon Master]]s need to play and run a horror-oriented campaign or integrate elements of creepiness & tension into their existing campaigns. }} {{Book list | title = ''[[Libris Mortis]]'' | author = [[Andy Collins (game designer)|Andy Collins]], [[Bruce Cordell|Bruce R. Cordell]] | publish_date = October 14, 2004 | isbn = 978-0-7869-3433-1 | aux1 = 192 | short_summary = This title takes a comprehensive look at undead creatures and characters in the D&D world. }} {{Book list | title = ''[[Lords of Madness]]'' | author = [[Richard Baker (game designer)|Richard Baker]], [[James Jacobs (game designer)|James Jacobs]], [[Steve Winter]] | publish_date = April 14, 2005 | isbn = 978-0-7869-3657-1 | aux1 = 224 | short_summary = ''[[Lords of Madness]]'' takes a comprehensive look at the most bizarre monsters of the ''[[D&D]]'' world, and the heroes who fight them. }} {{Book list | title = ''[[Magic Item Compendium]]'' | author = [[Andy Collins (game designer)|Andy Collins]], [[Mike Mearls]], Stephen Schubert, Eytan Bernstein, Frank Brunner, [[John Snead]], [[Owen K.C. Stephens]] | publish_date = March 13, 2007 | isbn = 978-0-7869-4345-6 | aux1 = 224 | short_summary = }} {{Book list | title = ''[[Magic of Incarnum]]'' | author = [[James Wyatt (game designer)|James Wyatt]], Frank Brunner, Stephen Schubert | publish_date = September 22, 2005 | isbn = 978-0-7869-3701-1 | aux1 = 224 | short_summary = With this book, the players characters can meld incarnum—the power of souls living, dead, and unborn—into magical items and even their own bodies, granting them special attacks, defenses, and other abilities (much as magic items and spells do). }} {{Book list | title = ''[[Manual of the Planes]]'' | author = [[Jeff Grubb]], [[Bruce Cordell|Bruce R. Cordell]], [[David Noonan (game designer)|David Noonan]] | publish_date = September 1, 2001 | isbn = 978-0-7869-1850-8 | aux1 = 224 | short_summary = This supplement for the D&D game provides everything you need to know before you visit other planes of existence. }} {{Book list | title = ''[[Masters of the Wild]]'' | author = [[Mike Selinker]], David Eckelberry | publish_date = February 1, 2002 | isbn = 978-0-7869-2653-4 | aux1 = 96 | short_summary = }} {{Book list | title = ''[[Miniatures Handbook]]'' | author = [[Jonathan Tweet]], Mike Donais, [[Skaff Elias]], [[Bruce Cordell|Bruce R. Cordell]], Kolja Raven Liquette, Travis Stout | publish_date = May 1, 2005 | isbn = 978-0-7869-3688-5 | aux1 = 224 | short_summary = }} |} ==''Dungeons & Dragons'' 4th edition== The books from the "main" product line of [[Dungeons & Dragons 4th edition|4th Edition]] are split into Core Rules and Supplement books. Unlike third edition of ''Dungeons & Dragons'', which had the core rulebooks released in monthly installments, the 4th editions of the ''Player's Handbook'', ''Monster Manual'', and ''Dungeon Master's Guide'' were all released in June 2008. In addition, beginning in September 2010 the stand-alone [[Dungeons & Dragons Essentials|''Essentials'' product line]] was released, aiming at novice players. ;Preview releases {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margins:auto; {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2015}} '''Nicky Imber''' ([[Vienna]] 1920 -1996) was a multidisciplinary Jewish artist best known for his sculptures on Jewish themes. Grand nephew of [[Naftali Herz Imber]], author of the Israeli national anthem '[[Hatikva]]'. [[File:Nicky Imber working on head.jpg|thumb|250px|Nicky Imber working on sculpture]] After escaping the Nazi concentration camp in [[Dachau]],The Daily Journal Friday September 22, 1972 he pledged to dedicate his art to perpetuating the memory of the Holocaust. Among his more famous works are "[[The Hope (Imber)|The Hope]]" and "The Love of Torah". His work can be seen around the world, in [[Northern Israel]], the [[United States]], and the Venezuelan Museum of Natural History in Caracas. == Biography== Nicky Imber was born in [[Vienna]], Austria. During his studies at the Academy of Arts in Vienna, he drew anti-Nazi caricatures for Jewish student publications.Meir Hareuveni, Ma'ariv newspaper, September 22, 1981 After several thwarted attempts by the family to leave Vienna, in 1938, in the wake of the '[[Anschluss]]', Imber was deported to [[Dachau]]. Witnessing the murders of family and friends, he plotted his escape. Using skills he had learned in art school, he made a face mask out of bread and sand, stole a Nazi soldier's uniform and walked out the front gate unnoticed.Letter from [[Carmiel]],1981 Yad Vashem Archives In 1940, he boarded a ship headed to [[Haifa]]. The ship's passengers were refused entry by the British mandatory authorities and imprisoned in a detention camp in [[Mauritius]]. In 1943, Imber worked out a deal with the authorities for his release by joining the British Army, serving as a war artist and a dental assistant in East Africa. After the war, he opened an art school in [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]], and worked as a photographer and a safari guide. In 1949 to 1954, he lived in [[Venezuela]], where he was contracted to do an East African [[Diorama]] series. The National Museum added an entire wing to display it.Ve Venezuela Vol.2 No.56 April–May 1975
During this period he got married and had a daughter Raquel, who accompanied and assisted him. [[File:Nicky Imber with one of the sculptures of the prehistoric animals.jpg|thumb|Nicky Imber with one of his prehistoric animal sculptures]] In 1959, Imber was commissioned to create sculptures and dioramas for the Haifa Prehistory Museum at Gan Ha-em in [[Haifa]], Israel. In 1960 he returned to Venezuela to restaured the Phelps series of Dioramas for the Museum in Caracas.Münstersche Zeitung Friday August 22, 1980 Between 1961 and 1971 he travelled extensively around Europe and after establishing an international name for himself, returned to the United States. In New York he became famous for his realistic oil paintings of portraits of [[Aga Khan]], [[Tyrone Power]], [[Ava Gardner]], [[David Ben-Gurion]], [[Golda Meir]], [[Sir Richard Burton]] and [[Simon Bolivar]].The Sun Reporter Tuesday July 31, 1973 Returning to Venezuela in 1976, Imber created huge sculptures of prehistoric animals, forming one of the world's largest historical animal parks. During this period he also created realistic sculptures of famous Venezuelans for the country's National Hall of Fame.El Nacional, Caracas, Thursday, April 22, 1976
In 1978, Imber spent three years designing and building a Holocaust memorial park at the entrance to the city of [[Karmiel]] located in the Galilee, entitled 'From Holocaust to Resurrection.' Imber also established animal theme playgrounds around the city. [[File:Nicky Imber building "Hope" in Carmiel, Israel.JPG|thumb|Nicky Imber building "Hope" in Carmiel, Israel]] In the 1980s, Imber established residence in Karmiel, Israel. In Israel he was inspired to create highly emotional, life like collections. Nicky Imber died in 1996 in Vienna, Austria. ==See also== *[[Visual arts in Israel]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *{{official website|http://nicky-imber.com/}} * Diana Lerner, Imberman dream of "City of Dreams", Ma'ariv, December 24, 1959 {{DEFAULTSORT:Imber, Nicky}} [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:1920 births]] [[Category:1996 deaths]] [[Category:Artists from Vienna]] [[Category:Jewish artists]] [[Category:Dachau concentration camp survivors]]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Norishige.jpg|thumb|150px|A ''Soshu'' school katana attributed to Etchu Norishige and ranked ''Tokubetsu Juyo Token'' by the NBTHK.]] The '''''Nihon Bijutsu Token Hozon Kyokai''''' ({{Nihongo|日本美術刀剣保存協会}}) ('''NBTHK''') or '''Society for the Preservation of Japanese Art Swords''' is an agency of the [[Government of Japan|Japanese government]] whose remit is the registration and preservation of antique [[Japanese sword|swords]].
The [[Agency for Cultural Affairs|Japanese Cultural Affairs Agency]] founded the NBTHK in 1948, in response to the [[Occupied Japan|Allied prohibition]] on Japanese swords after [[World War Two]].<ref name=probe>{{cite web|title=Police Raid Society for Preservation of Japanese Art Swords|url=http://www.japanprobe.com/2010/09/30/police-raid-society-for-preservation-of-japanese-art-swords/|publisher=Japan Probe|accessdate=29 April 2013}}</ref><ref name="RousmaniereMuseum2007">{{cite book|author1=Nicole Coolidge Rousmaniere|author2=British Museum|author3=Kokuritsu Kindai Bijutsukan (Japan) |author4=Kyōto Kokuritsu Kindai Bijutsukan |author5=Nihon Kōgeikai |author6=Kokusai Kōryū Kikin|title=Crafting beauty in modern Japan: celebrating fifty years of the Japan traditional art crafts exhibition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yRnrAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=29 April 2013|date=30 August 2007|publisher=University of Washington Press|isbn=978-0-295-98733-0|page=13}}</ref>
The NBTHK holds annual competitions for modern swordsmiths, which is the highlight of the Japanese sword-making calendar. Success in this competition is a high accolade.<ref name="KappKapp2002">{{cite book|author1=Leon Kapp|author2=Hiroko T. Kapp|author3=Yoshindo Yoshihara|title=Modern Japanese Swords and Swordsmiths: From 1866 to the Present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c7YeN0F5tn4C&pg=PA7|accessdate=29 April 2013|year=2002|publisher=Kodansha International|isbn=978-4-7700-1962-2|pages=7}}</ref>
The Society issues certification for antique swords. There are four levels of classification in this system: ''hozon'' (worthy of preservation), ''tokubetsu hozon'' (high value work worthy of preservation), ''juyo token'' (important sword) and ''tokubetsu juyo token'' (highest value and importance).<ref>{{cite book|title=Worth|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3-IJAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=29 April 2013|year=2007|publisher=CurtCo. Publishing|page=84}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Tosogu Kanteisho|url=http://www.jssus.org/nkp/tosogu_kanteisho.html|publisher=Nihonto Kanji|accessdate=29 April 2013}}</ref> Certification by the NBTHK can increase the resale value of a sword tenfold.<ref name="ConnorSiler2009">{{cite book|author1=Myles J. Connor|author2=Jenny Siler|title=The Art of the Heist: Confessions of a Master Art Thief, Rock-and-Roller, and Prodigal Son|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z4TrAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=29 April 2013|date=21 April 2009|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0-06-167228-6|page=132}}</ref> The NBTHK is also responsible for the Japanese Sword Museum in [[Tokyo]].<ref name=probe/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.nbthk-ab.org/Japan.htm NBTHK website] * [http://www.touken.or.jp/english/ Japanese Sword Museum]
[[Category:Japanese culture]] [[Category:Japanese swords]] [[Category:Arts in Japan]]

revision.text:
{{redirect-distinguish|Open access book|Open textbook}} An '''open-access monograph''' is a scholarly [[monograph]] which is made freely available with a [[Creative Commons Licence|creative commons licence.]]<ref>{{Cite web|title = Budapest Open Access Initiative {{!}} Budapest Open Access Initiative|url = http://www.budapestopenaccessinitiative.org/|website = www.budapestopenaccessinitiative.org|accessdate = 2015-10-22}}</ref>
==Concept== Open access is when academic research is made freely available for anyone to read and re-use.<ref>{{cite web|title=Berlin Declaration on Open Access to Knowledge in the Sciences and Humanities|url=http://openaccess.mpg.de/286432/Berlin-Declaration|website=Max Planck Open Access|accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref> As with [[open access journals]], there are different [[business models]] for funding open-access books, including [[Article processing charge|publication charges]], institutional support, [[library publishing]], and consortium models.<ref name=insights>{{cite journal|last1=Ferwerda|first1=Eelco|title=Open access monograph business models|journal=Insights|date=2014|volume=27|doi=10.1629/2048-7754.118|url=http://uksg.metapress.com/content/e17587x1kn27p705/fulltext.pdf|accessdate=10 June 2014|issn=2048-7754}}</ref> OECD Publishing uses a [[freemium]] model by making its books available online in HTML with the option to purchase a print copy.<ref name=insights /> There is some evidence that making electronic editions of books open access can increase sales of the print edition.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Suber|first1=Peter|title=Open access|url=http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/hoap/Open_Access_(the_book)|date=2012|publisher=MIT Press|isbn=9780262517638|page=107|accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref>
==History== While open access to journal articles has become very common, with 50% of articles published in 2011 available as open access,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Archambault|first1=Eric|last2=Amyot|first2=Didier|last3=Deschamps|first3=Philippe|last4=Nicol,|first4=Aurore|last5=Rebout|first5=Lise|last6=Roberge|first6=Guillaume|title=Proportion of Open Access Peer-Reviewed Papers at the European and World Levels—2004-2011|url=http://www.science-metrix.com/pdf/SM_EC_OA_Availability_2004-2011.pdf|accessdate=4 June 2014|date=August 2013}}</ref> open access to books has not yet seen as much uptake.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Collins|first1=Ellen|last2=Milloy|first2=Caren|title=A snapshot of attitudes towards open access monograph publishing in the humanities and social sciences – part of the OAPEN-UK project|journal=Insights|date=2012|volume=25|issue=2|doi=10.1629/2048-7754.25.2.192|url=http://uksg.metapress.com/content/727t2j1u17uvgnt2/fulltext.pdf|accessdate=10 June 2014}}</ref> However, there are dedicated open-access book publishers such as [[Open Book Publishers]] and others who publish both books and journals, such as [[Open Humanities Press]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bonn|first1=Maria|title=Free exchange of ideas Experimenting with the open access monograph|url=http://crln.acrl.org/content/71/8/436.short|website=College & Research Libraries News|accessdate=10 June 2014}}</ref> A report released in 2015 by the UK's main funding body for research, the [[Higher Education Funding Council for England]], states the importance of open access monographs:<ref>{{cite web|title=Monographs and open access: A report to HEFCE|url=http://www.hefce.ac.uk/media/hefce/content/pubs/indirreports/2015/Monographs,and,open,access/2014_monographs.pdf|accessdate=21 August 2015|date=August 2013}}</ref> "Monographs are a vitally important and distinctive vehicle for research communication, and must be sustained in any moves to open access."<ref>{{cite web|title=Monographs and open access|url=http://www.hefce.ac.uk/pubs/rereports/year/2015/monographs/|accessdate=21 August 2015|date=August 2013}}</ref>
The Open Access Publishing in European Networks (OAPEN) project provides access to hundreds of peer-reviewed academic books, mainly in the humanities and social sciences.<ref>{{cite web|title=Joining OAPEN|url=http://www.oapen.org/about?page=join|website=OAPEN|accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Open Educational Resources]] *[[re.press]] *[[Open Library of Humanities]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * "Monographs", p. 112 in Martin Paul Eve, ''Open Access and the Humanities'', [[Cambridge University Press]], 2014. {{sister-inline |project=wikisource |short=yes |links=[[:wikisource:Open access and the humanities/Chapter 4|full text]] }} * "Open-access monographs", p. 419 in Peggy Johnson, ''Fundamentals of Collection Development and Management'', [[American Library Association]], 2014.
==External links== *[http://www.oapen.org/home OAPEN Library] *[http://www.doabooks.org/ Directory of Open Access Books] * [[Open Access Directory]] - [http://oad.simmons.edu/oadwiki/Publishers_of_OA_books List of publishers of OA books]. {{oclc|757073363}} * Open Access Directory - [http://oad.simmons.edu/oadwiki/OA_book_business_models List of OA book business models] *[http://www.openoasis.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=348&Itemid=381 Open Access Scholarly Information Sourcebook - Open Access Monographs]
{{Books}} {{Open access navbox}} [[Category:Open access (publishing)|Monograph]] [[Category:Book publishing]]
